bboxes.raw_text:
COOLIDGE About two dozen
Negroes picketed the Truckers
Cafe here after they we're refused
service inside, Police Chief Da-
vid Satterfield reported.


Satterfield said the demonstra-
ton was peaceful and the Negroes
prevented no one from entering
the cafe.


The cafe owners. Mr.. and Mrs.
lack Brakeman, told the Negroes
they could be served food to take
out, but not to be eaten inside.


The Negroes we're members
of the National Association for
the Advancement of Colored
People.


The cafe was the scene of an
incident between Negroes and
whites earlier this year.


Early in July. Roy M. Twitty.
Negro from Tues on, filed COM
plant with U. W. Atty. Carl A.
Muecke in Phoenix, saying he had
been refused service at the cafe.


Muecke said he turned the COM
plant over to the Federal Bureau
of Investigation since the City Of
Coolidge had no civil rights or
public accommodation ordinance.


Muecke said, II met with Coo
lidge city officials last Thursday
in an attempt to get this matter
worked out on a voluntary basis.
| think that would be much better
than going to court.

Two bills recently signed into
law by President Johnson will
benefit veterans who hold Ma
uonal Service Life Insurance
policies, Wayne Sanders. Mana
ger Of VAS Arizona Regional
Office said.


More than 81 r. million World
War II and Korean veteran policy
holders will benefit from an ex-
tension of premium waiver pro-
Visions. Now the law provides
for the waiver of premiums if
the insured becomes totally dis
abled before his Goth birthday.


This second law also takes

effect on January l, 1865.


Service disabled veterans
holding "RH" insurance poll
cies will not be eligible for this
new total disability income pro-
vision.


Those who are eligible mustb be
in good health. They must file
an application and must pay an
additional premium.


Sanders pointed out that appli-
cation forms for the disability
riders will be available this fall.
CT policyholders affected will be
advised.

Robert Brown Elliott, free
Negro born in Boston on Aug. IL.
1912, graduated from Elton Col
lege in England.

He served as congressman
from South Carolina in the 42nd
and 43rd sessions atWashington,
D. c.

full articles.headline: Eton Grad Served in Congress
full articles.article:
Robert Brown Elliott, free
Negro born in Boston on Aug. IL.
1912, graduated from Elton Col
lege in England.

He served as congressman
from South Carolina in the 42nd
and 43rd sessions atWashington,
